com.itko.util

Class ParameterList

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.util.ParameterList
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    CloneImplemented, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<Parameter>

    public class ParameterList
extends java.lang.Object
implements CloneImplemented, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Iterable<Parameter>
    This class implements a collection for Parameter objects. Use this to have a handy way to construct and spit back out the parameters in a variety of formats. There are all kinds of useful features here. For example, it will construct a ParameterList object out of an XML DOM Element. The collection here maintains the order of the Parameters; can find by key name, can have duplicates, and supports saving to a variety of string types.
    Version:
    1
    See Also:
    for more on the individual parameters, Serialized Form

        Constructs a parameter list out of a string. The string looks like: "thiskey=thisvalue&thisotherkey=thisothervalue&singleton&anotherkey=anothervalue"

        mergeDupesDelimiter - - the delimiter to use for merging dupe key values; pass DEF_MERGE_DUPE_VALUES_DELIM to get what this class uses by default

      • ParameterList

        public ParameterList(org.w3c.dom.Element parent)
        This constructor will build a ParameterList object from the given XML Node. It does this from a rather contrived method but hopefully useful. It reads all the parent node attributes as Parameters, and then adds every child node as a Parameter. The child node name is the key and its child text is its value. Attributes in child nodes are added as well.

        Parameters:
        parent - - the parent DOM Element for this new parameters collection

        For more info on how this actually works, see the following:
        ParameterList#addNodeAttributes ParameterList#addChildNodes

      • ParameterList

        public ParameterList(boolean dupesAllowed)
        Constructs an empty parameter list, setting the allows dupes flag (it does allow dupes by default)
        Parameters:
        dupesAllowed - true to allow duplicate keys

      • setAllowDupes

        public void setAllowDupes(boolean allowDupes)
        Tell us whether to allow duplicate keys in the collection. Note that we will not make sure any existing contents are consistent with this setting. The default value of this, unless set by the consumer of this class, is true
        Parameters:
        allowDupes - - to tell us whether to replace instead of append dupe keys

      • isDupesAllowed

        true if duplicate keys are allowed in the collection

        public void setEncoded(boolean encoded)

        Parameters:
        encoded - - to tell us whether values are URL-encoded in the collection

      • getMergeDupesDelimiter

        public java.lang.String getMergeDupesDelimiter()

      • setMergeDupesDelimiter

        public void setMergeDupesDelimiter(java.lang.String mergeDupesDelimiter)
        Providing a delimiter has the affect of not allowing dupe keys in the list, but instead of just ignoring them, it appends the dupe value to the existing parameter. So for example, existing params are key1=v1&key2=v2, and you call this method with "|", then adding a param of key2=v3 will cause the list to look like "key1=v1&key2=v2|v3"
        Parameters:
        mergeDupesDelimiter - the token to use to separate dupe values for a given key

      • addParameters

        public void addParameters(java.lang.String paramData)
        Adds the set of Parameter objects that can be parsed from the given String. The string is expected in the form key1=v1&key2=v2.
        Parameters:
        paramData - the additional Parameters you want added to this List

      • addParameters

                 boolean encoded)
        Adds the set of Parameter objects that can be parsed from the given String. The string is expected in the form key1=v1&key2=v2.
        Parameters:
        paramData - the additional Parameters you want added to this List
        encoded - a flag indicating whether the string should be URL decoded or not.

      • clone

        public java.lang.Object clone()
        Does a deep copy of the current object into a new ParameterList object. By deep I mean that it clones the terms so the two ParameterList objects don't reference the same terms.
        Specified by:
        clone in interface CloneImplemented
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a ParameterList with its own collection of the Parameters

      • cloneQuick

        public ParameterList cloneQuick()
        Does a shallow copy of the current object into a new ParameterList object. This method is more performant than clone().

      • hasMatchingParameter

        public boolean hasMatchingParameter(Parameter p)
        This method does a value-based comparison of the parameter list for the given parameter. It _does_ if a parameter in the list has the given parameter's same key and value.

      • addChildNodes

        public void addChildNodes(org.w3c.dom.Element parent)
        Given a parent XML DOM Element, this method will add all the child nodes' attributes as parameters, plus any child text elements as Parameters with the key of the element name and the value of the child text. Here's an example: 
         <Parent>
   <Sub1 key1=value>text</Sub1>
   <key2>value2</key2>
 </Parent>
        Will add the following: key1=value&Sub1=text&key2=value2
        Parameters:
        parent -

      • getParameterValue

        public java.lang.String getParameterValue(java.lang.String key)
        Method used to retrieve the value side of a Parameter. If the term is a singleton, then we return the term name as its value (they are the same). Will return null if it can't find it.
        Parameters:
        key - - the key for the parameter to find
        Returns:
        the String of the value of the parameter or null if not found

      • setParameterValue

        public void setParameterValue(java.lang.String key,
                     java.lang.String value)
        Sometimes you want to allow for duplicate values in a list but you want the ability to set a parameter value as if you didn't. This method will check for an existing parameter known by the given key. If one exists, its value will be updated. If it does not exist, then a new parameter will be added.
        Parameters:
        key - the key to the parameter to update.
        value - the (possibly new) value for named parameter.

      • toAttributeString

        public java.lang.String toAttributeString()
        An attribute string doesn't use the & between terms. Instead, it's useful for building an XML attribut string.
        For example, key1=value1&singleton&key2=value2 in the list would be constructed like that as a string from the toArgumentString() method. But this method would construct that string as "key1=\"value1\" singleton key2=\"value2\"".
        Returns:
        string as described above

      • writeXMLString

        public java.lang.String writeXMLString(int indent)
        Builds an element string out of the list. While an argument string might look like "key1=value1&singleton&key2=value2", an element string would look like (note the new lines) 
         <key1>value1</key1>
        
 <singleton>singleton</singleton>
        
 <key2>value2</key2>
        The entire string will be indented by the given spaces
        Parameters:
        indent - - how many spaces to pad each "line" in the string
        Returns:
        element string

      • writeSimpleUnsafeXML

        public void writeSimpleUnsafeXML(java.io.PrintWriter pw,
                        int indent)
        Builds an element string out of the list. While an argument string might look like "key1=value1&singleton&key2=value2", an element string would look like (note the new lines) 
         <key1>value1</key1>
        
 <singleton>singleton</singleton>
        
 <key2>value2</key2>
        The entire string will be indented by the given spaces

      • writeXML

        public void writeXML(java.io.PrintWriter pw,
            int indent,
            boolean writeTypeMap,
            boolean usesUnicode)

      • writeXML

        public void writeXML(java.io.PrintWriter pw,
            int indent)
        This method generates the Parameter Terms into an XML-like series of child nodes. For example, 
         <Key1>value1</Key1>
 <Key2>value2</Key2>
        Singleton Terms will have the same Tag and inner text.
        Parameters:
        pw - is the Writer to be filled with this result
        indent - is a number of spaces to prepend to every output line.

      • writeXML

        public void writeXML(java.io.PrintWriter pw,
            int indent,
            boolean writeTypeMap)

      • writePropertyFile

        public void writePropertyFile(java.io.PrintWriter ps)

      • writeEncryptedPropsFile

        public void writeEncryptedPropsFile(java.io.OutputStream os)
        Write the properties to the given OutputStream. This is the preferred method because CR/LF characters are handled in a way consistent with the java.util.Properties.load() method. Specifically, this method uses java.util.Properties.store() to write out the properties. The store() method encodes newlines within the property value so that the newlines are preserved. That is, if you have the property: colors=red[newline]green[newline]blue[endofline] those newlines within the value are preserved when reading and writing.
        Parameters:
        os - the file to which the properties are written

      • writeEncryptedPropsFile

        public void writeEncryptedPropsFile(java.io.PrintWriter ps)
        Deprecated. Please use ( OutputStream )
        Writes the parameters to the given PrintWriter.
